text:
```julia> s = Set{String}(["asd"])
julia> in(s, "asd")
false
julia> in("asd", s")
true```
I know the argument order is meant to be read as `"asd" in s`, but it's still an easy mistake to make - and the fact that the alternative definition also exists, and returns false, is very dangerous!

elements.text:
julia> s = Set{String}(["asd"])
julia> in(s, "asd")
false
julia> in("asd", s")
true
I know the argument order is meant to be read as
, but it's still an easy mistake to make - and the fact that the alternative definition also exists, and returns false, is very dangerous!

text: `in` can also be used, not just read, as infix operator
